newsitem.title: KYRGYZSTAN: Kyrgyz economy grows 5.4 percent in 1996.
newsitem.headline: Kyrgyz economy grows 5.4 percent in 1996.

text.p: Kyrgyzstan's gross domestic product (GDP) grew 5.4 percent last year, compared with a 6.2-percent fall in 1995, and is expected to continue growing this year, a senior official said on Monday.

Zhumakadyr Akeneyev, head of the National Statistics Committee, told a news conference 1996 GDP grew because of a 10.8-percent rise in industry output and a 13.0-percent jump in agricultural output. In 1995, industry output fell 12.5 percent.
But inflation in the mountainous Central Asian country was faster than targeted, rising 35 percent instead of the planned 32 percent. Inflation was 31.2 percent in 1995.
The former Soviet republic's trade performance was also disappointing, with the deficit widening last year to $300 million from $50 million in 1995.

But other data encouraged government optimism. State investment in all spheres of production grew by 16 percent last year, and the economy's private sector accounts for more than two-thirds of the country's GDP.
